title: The Archaic Record At Lubbock Lake
abstract: The Lubbock Lake site, on the Llano Estacada of Texas, is best known as a Paleo-Indian locality, but it also has produced a considerable Archaic record. Archaic materials, from substratum 2e and strata 3 and 4, were found by all investigators at the site since excavations began in 1939. Substratum 2e is a sandy eolian unit deposited sometime between 8500 and 6400 years B.P. One Early Archaic feature was found in substratum 2e. Stratum 3 contains valley-margin eolian deposits, valleyaxis lacustrine sediments, and the Yellowhouse Soil. Sedimentation and soil formation occurred from 6400 to as late as 5000 years B.P. The beginning age of soil formation is unknown. Stratum 3 yielded six Middle Archaic features representing probable camping events. Stratum 4 consists of marsh sediments accumulated from 5500 to 1000 years B.P. and eolian material deposited between about 5000 and 4500 years B.P. The Lubbock Lake Soil formed in stratum 4 from 4500 to 1000 years B.P. and locally is still forming. Stratum 4 contained at least 22 Middle Archaic features, including several Bison bison bone beds, numerous camping areas and hearths, and a large oven probably used for vegetal processing. The Late Archaic is represented by nine features composed of camping debris and a hearth found within the buried A horizon of the Lubbock Lake Soil. However, because this horizon represents a stable land surface that existed well into the Ceramic period, Archaic and later materials probably are mixed. Available data indicate that during the period 6400 to 4500 years B.P., two severe droughts occurred throughout at least the central Llano Estacada. The record at Lubbock Lake demonstrates that at least that area was not abandoned during this time of climatic stress, probably because water always was available. A proposed model for the Archaic on the Llano Estacada includes five shifts in the general mixed economy of plant and animal resources coinciding with climatic events. The model is one of in situ development with its basis in late Paleo-Indian times and continuing into the following period.

body_text.text: The Archaic period is the longest cultural period known on the llano Estacada, yet few Archaic localities are recognized, and of those reported, many are surface occurrences. The Archaic is that time span between the Paleo-Indian and Ceramic periods, generally considered to encompass the time from 8000 years B.P. to 2000 years B.P. (e.g., McKinney 1981; Weir 1976) . On the Llano Estacada, the Archaic arbitrarily was subdivided into Early (8000-6000 years B.P.), Middle (6000-4000 years B.P.), and Late (4000-2000 years B.P.) (Holliday 1977) . The only sites known on the Llano Estacada with evidence of extensive Archaic occupations in a deep stratified context are Blackwater Draw Locality #1 (Hester 1972) , Lubbock Lake, and possibly Chalk Hollow (Wedel 1975) . This paper is a discussion of the Archaic material recovered at Lubbock lake and includes a summary of the Archaic throughout the Llano Estacada and a brief review of the Archaic in neighboring areas.

lubbock lake (41LU1) is located in valley fill in an entrenched meander of Yellowhouse Draw within the city limits of Lubbock, Texas (Figs. 1, 2, 3) . The draw is a tributary of the Brazos River and is joined by Blackwater Draw about 6 km downstream from lubbock Lake to form Yellowhouse Canyon. lubbock Lake covers about 120 ha and has been designated both a State and National Historic Landmark. The Landmark is a complex of cultural activity areas with a virtually complete cultural, faunal, and floral record within a sequence of sediments and associated soils up to 8 m thick that span at least the past 11 ,500 years (Johnson 1976 (Johnson , 1983a Holliday 1982a Holliday , 1983 Holliday , 1985a Holliday et al. 1983 Holliday et al. , 1985 . Lubbock Lake was discovered in 1936 as a result of dredging in Yellowhouse Draw. A large, U-shaped reservoir excavated along the inside of the meander completely cut through the late Quaternary fill in the draw, thus exposing the cultural and stratigraphic sequence ( Fig. 3) .

Archaeological investigations took place intermittently at the site between the late 1930s and middle 1960s and on a continuous basis since 1972. Wheat (1974) conducted the first archaeological work (1939, 1941) through the then West Texas Museum (WTM) with WPA funding. Glen Evans and Grayson Meade (Sellards 1952) carried out further testing (1948, 1950, 1951) through the Texas Memorial Museum (TMM). Green (1962a) and Kelley (1974) performed additional work (1959, 1960) through the West Texas Museum. The current Lubbock Lake Project (LLP) is under the auspices of The Museum, Texas Tech University (TTU).

While the thrust of the various research programs has been in either the Paleo-Indian deposits or late prehistoric to historic deposits, some exploration and excavation have occurred in the deposits that encompass the Archaic period. This paper represents a first-approximation at interpretation of the data for the Archaic period generated from all the programs and, therefore, basically is descriptive in nature. The combined data demonstrate aboriginal occupation of the site during each of the major Archaic subdivisions and point to a potential detailed and continuous record over that approximate 6000year period unexplored elsewhere in the region.

The Llano Estacada ("Staked Plains") of northwest Texas and eastern New Mexico, also known as the Southern High Plains, is an extensive plateau covering approximately 130,000 km 2 • It is the southernmost portion of the High Plains section of the Great Plains physiographic province (Fig. 1) . The southern portion of the Osage Plains section of the Central Lowland Province is east of the eastern escarpment of the Llano Estacada. This region of north-central Texas and southwestern Oklahoma locally is known as the Rolling Plains. The Edwards Plateau and Central Texas sections of the Great Plains Province are to the south and southeast of the Llano Estacada. The Pecos Valley section, which includes the Mescalero (Querecho) Plains, is another division of the Great Plains and is west and southwest of the Llano Estacada (Hunt 1974; Fenneman 1931) . The Southern Plains is a general, informal term that includes the Llano Estacada, Mescalero Plains, and the southern Central Lowlands.

The Llano Estacada is defined by escarpments along the west, north, and east sides. The southern portion merges with the Edwards Plateau without an obvious topographic demarcation (Fenneman 1931; Hunt 197 4; Hawley et al. 1976) . The climate of the region is continental and semiarid and is classified as dry, midlatitude, and semidesert (Strahler and Strahler 1983:Piate C.2) .

The Llano Estacada has a virtually featureless, constructional surface that is one of the largest of its kind in the United States (NOAA 1982) . The surface was formed by deposition of thick, widespread eolian sediments (Blackwater Draw Formation) dur-llano Estacado

• Sites !!I Cities ing the Pleistocene. These sediments overlie the Ogallala Formation (Miocene-Pliocene) and, locally, the Blanco Formation (Pliocene). The surface of the Llano Estacada has been modified locally by formation of several dune fields; thousands of small, ephemeral lake basins formed by deflation; and several northwest-southeast-trending ephemeral drainages or draws (Fig. 2) , which are tributaries of the Red, Brazos, and Colorado rivers (Hawley et al. 1976 ; Reeves 1972 Reeves , 1976 .

investigations of late Quaternary stratigraphy and pedology have been an integral part of LLP research at Lubbock Lake limit of valley fill ::::m:nmn: reservoir cut (1936) ;;:i''()t!''; dredqe spoil (/936) Green) , and Lubbock Lake Project (Areas 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 12, and 16, and Trench 83) . Area 7 is equivalent to WTM blocks P and Q; Area 4 is equivalent to blocks M and N; Area 8 is equivalent to blocks A1, A, B, C, I, J, and K; and Area 12 is equivalent to blocks E, F, and G. (Johnson 1974; Stafford 1977 Stafford , 1978 Stafford , 1981 Holliday 1982a Holliday , 1983 Holliday , 1985a Holliday , 1985b . In the Lubbock area, Yellowhouse Draw has cut through the Blackwater Draw Formation and into the Blanco Formation (Fig. 4) . The draw attained a maximum relief of about 15 m in the latest Pleistocene (Stafford 1977) . The draw began to aggrade prior to about 11,000 years B.P. and has been filling intermittently throughout the Holocene. Five basic geologic units and five named soils formed therein have been identified at Lubbock lake. The five principal strata are numbered oldest to youngest. Vertical subdivisions (substrata) within each numbered unit are identified by an uppercase letter, alphabetically, oldest to youngest. Principal facies within a given stratum or substratum are identified by a lowercase letter (/ = lacustrine, e = eolian, s = slopewash). The chronology of all strata and soils is well controlled by numerous radiocarbon ages (Holliday et al. 1983, 1 985) . All cited ages are given in radiocarbon years B.P. The following discussion of the Archaic geology is summarized from Holliday (1985a, 1985b, 1985c) and Holliday et al. (1983 Holliday et al. ( , 1985 .

The Archaic cultural remains at Lubbock lake are found in substratum 2e and throughout strata 3 and 4 ( Fig. 4) . Stratum 2 is a lacustrine (2A) and marsh (28) unit deposited between 11,000 and 8500 years B.P. During the Early Archaic (8500-6400 years B.P.), the Firstview Soil formed in upper substratum 28. Along the valley axis, the soil formed under poorly drained conditions with water near and probably at times at the surface. Along the valley margin, the soil formed under better drained conditions. Although the potential exists for an Early Archaic record within this soil, as of yet, cultural materials have not been found. Along the west and south sides of the va~ley, however, sandy sediments (substratum 2e) up to 50 em thick accumulated as the Firstview Soil was forming. These deposits comprise substratum 2F of Stafford (1981) and Holliday (1985a) . Although Stafford (1981) considered these sands to be re!ated to spring discharge, Holliday and Johnson (1982) noted that direct field evidence for spring discharge was lacking. Holliday (1985a) suggested that these sands may be eolian sediments, which now has been confirmed by evidence from scanning electron micrography. The SEM micrographs show that quartz grains in the unit were subjected to eolian transport. These sands, therefore, represent a transgression of the eolian facies of stratum 2, substratum 2e (Homday 1 985a), across substratum 28. Substratum 2e typically is reddish-brown where it is identified in well-drained upslope positions along the western and southern valley margins. The sands in the poorly drained environment of the valley axis are olive colors.

Stratum 3 is comformable on stratum 2, ranges from 30 em to over 1 m thick, and is composed of two facies, substrata 3e and 3/. Substratum 3e is found along the western valley margin ( Fig. 3 ) and is a moderately calcareous, massive to weak subangular blocky, sandy loam ranging in color from dark brown (moist) to light brown (dry). This deposit is considered to be eoiian with some additions of slopewash near the valley margins. Substratum 3/ is a lacustrine facies of 3e, found along the va!!ey axis (Fig. 3) . The deposit is a highly calcareous silty clay loam to silty clay, white (dry) to dark grayish brown (moist), with massive to platy structure.

The Yellowhouse Soil formed in stratum 3. This soil has A-C (valley-axis and valleymargin facies) and sometimes weak A-B-C (valley-margin only) profiles, reflecting the facies changes of the parent material. The highly calcareous valley-axis facies exhibits relatively high organic carbon content with a mollie A horizon and minimal leaching of carbonate in the C horizon. This condition suggests that the water table along the axis of the draw remained high during deposition of the parent material and throughout pedogenesis. Deposition of stratum 3 began around 6400 years B.P. The end of deposition and the beginning of the formation of the Yellowhouse Soil is unknown. Burial of stratum 3 and the soil was time-transgressive. Along the valley-axis, stratum 3 was eroded and buried by substratum 4A beginning by about 5500 years B.P. Along the valley margin, stratum 3 and its soil were not buried until as late as 5000 years B.P.

Stratum 4 consists of substrata 4A, 48, and 4/. Substratum 4A (less than 1 m thick:) is found only along the valley axis and is composed of sandy, low-energy alluvial deposits with interbedded, clayey backwater/lowland marsh deposits. Substratum 4B (1-2 m thick) is a sandy eolian deposit. Substratum 4/ is a lowland marsh deposit found only along the valley axis, is a lateral equivalent of 4A and 48, and overlies 48.

The Lubbock Lake Soil formed in substratum 4B. It is the best developed Holocene soil observed on the Llano Estacada (Holliday 1982a) . The soil exhibits mollie or ochric A horizons and, usually, an argillic and, along the valley-axis, a partially gleyed B horizon, and often multiple calcic horizons.

Deposition of 4A occurred between 5500 and 5000 years B.P., and 48 occurred between 5500 and 4500 years B.P. Substratum 41 was deposited during this time and throughout formation of the Lubbock Lake Soil. The soil began forming around 4500 years B.P. after 48 deposition. Where stratum 4 is buried by stratum 5, soil formation ceased a little less than 1000 years B.P. Where stratum 4 has not been buried, pedogenesis of the Lubbock Lake Soil continues today. In either situation, the surface represented by the upper portion of the A horizon existed during Late Archaic and later occupations.

All investigators at Lubbock Lake since the discovery of the site have employed their own stratigraphic terminology. An attempt at correlating the terminology is presented in Table 1 . A few comments are in order concerning the correlations and their inherent uncertainties. Probably the most confusing aspect of the ear~ier stratigraphic terminology is the assignment of stratigraphic nomenclature to pedologic features. The A horizon of the lubbock Lake Soil was designated "Stratum IVa" and "Stratum V" by Wheat (1974) , "Stratum 5" by Green (1962a; Kaczor 1978) , and "substratum 4C" by Johnson (1974) and Stafford (1981) . The parent material of the A horizon (substratum 48) was deposited not later than about 4500 years B.P., and the soil formed since then. Individual soil horizons do not have stratigraphic significance. (Holliday 1982a , 1983 , 1985a , (Stafford 1981 (Wheat 197 4 ) (Green 1962a; (Evans 1949; 1985b , 1985c , this paper) Johnson 1974) Trench A, Kelley 1974 The time span encompassed by soil formation led to some of the confusion concerning artifact provenience (e.g., Kelley 1974) . Late Archaic or Ceramic age material easily could have been and undoubtedly was worked into upper 4B through bioturbation after the material was left on the surface represented by the A horizon. Where stratum 4 was not buried, younger aged material undoubtedly also occurs. Material recovered from the uppermost portion of the A horizon, therefore, probably has been disturbed and may well represent a mixture of several thousand years of cultural history. Material deeper in the A horizon probably has been less disturbed.

Very limited information also suggests that Wheat's (1974) Stratum IVc is the zone of secondary calcium carbonate accumulation in the lower Lubbock Lake Soil. On the southwest side of the site, where the WPA work was concentrated ( Fig. 3 ), this calcic horizon formed in lower substratum 4B and upper substratum 3e and is superimposed over the upper portion of the Yellowhouse Soil in the latter unit. Moving toward the valley margin (to the southwest), the calcic horizon developed nearer the surface and entirely is within substratum 4B. Exactly where along WPA Trench A West the calcic horizon becomes wholely contained within 48 is not known. Wheat (1974:Fig. 1 ) also indicated that his Stratum IVc extended southwest along Trench• A beyond the bedrock valley wall (Blanco Formation; WPA units A-G). Available geologic data now suggest that IVc beyond the valley wall (starting at WPA Unit 270) probably is the calcic horizon of a soil formed in LLP stratum 5.

The lack of adequate information for much of the earlier work also has hindered correlations. During Wheat's (1974) excavations at Lubbock Lake, a long trench and adjacent unit ( Fig. 3) were opened up on the west side of the reservoir. In that trenching, both lithic and bone materials were recovered from strata 3 and 4. Although confusion existed in earlier reports (Kelley 1974; Alexander 1978; Wheat 1974) as to the provenience, age, or significance of these materials, LLP stratigraphic trenching on the west side, analysis of the sediments still adhering to the artifacts, and correlation of Wheat's (1974) data with LLP data (Table 1 ) clarify the matter of artifact placement and paleotopography. Kelley (1974) presented an involved discussion of "Zones A, B, C, and D" of "Stratum 4" from Green's (1962a) work. Resolving these problems is difficult, however, because information is not available on "Zones C and D." The correlations for these units (Table 1) are based solely on description. Kelley (1974:68) also discussed a group of artifacts recovered during the WPA excavations from below Wheat's (1974) Stratum IV. This discussion led Alexander (1978:21) to conclude that pre-Clovis material had been found at Lubbock Lake in "middle or early Pleistocene" clays. Artifacts were recovered from the surface and within cracks of the Blanco Formation (Pliocene) bedrock along the valley walls on the southwest side of the site where the unit was exposed to weathering during the early Holocene. The artifacts are Archaic tools reworked into the blocky, highly friable Blanco clay at the point where substratum 4B onlaps the bedrock.

During the LLP excavations, numerous cultural levels were defined within the various strata and delineated through the designation of features in each excavation area. Features constitute distinct units of concentrated cultural materials that represent occupation floors or unusual natural occurrences, generally with relatively sterile deposits above and below them. This view was modified to accommodate the limited data when assigning feature designations to the materials recovered from the previous investigations.

Features in each excavation area were assigned a serial number as they were encountered, and that number is retained permanently by the feature in subsequent excavations. The LLP designation for features translate as Feature, Area number-serial number (e.g., FA5-4). Green's (1962a) , Kelley's (1974) , and Wheat's (1974) occupation levels were given feature designations when they were correlated with LLP data (Table 2) , denoted by the initial of the investigator (e.g., GA5-1, Green's Area 5, feature 1 ). Both humans and large carnivores were bone modifiers at Lubbock Lake. Wolf (Canis lupus) was the primary large carnivore through time. Some of the Lubbock Lake bones exhibit a complex life history of both human-induced and carnivore-induced damage. Carnivore damage and disturbance were taken into account and any questionable specimens and damage discounted when analyzing the Lubbock Lake faunal material for game animal determinations, marrow processing, and butchering patterns (see Johnson 1985 for a detailed discussion on bone fracture mechanics and distinguishing carnivore from human-induced modifications).

The Lubbock Lake faunal remains from all explorations into the Archaic deposits were examined closely in order to determine the role of marrow processing, bone as a material resource, and tool use and production. Isolating the categories of human-induced modifications and identifying specimens within those categories were based on: (1} key characters that indicated dynamic loading of fresh bones (e.g., helical fracture, impact point, hackle marks} in contrast to carnivore action characters; and (2} characters that point to subsequent use. Use-wear constitutes localized and restricted post-fracturing bone removal along the fractured edge. Usewear characters were compared with the kinds and location of damage produced by carnivores, and specimens designated as tools generally lack carnivore damage (Johnson 1985}.

Holliday and Welty (1981} described the resources available in the region for manufacture of lithic tools and presented the basic terminology for the various rock types. A significant portion of the Lubbock Lake lithic artifact inventory from the Archaic period is made of fine-grained chert that varies in color from tan to light, medium, and dark gray, and dark blue. Although this material is referred to as Edwards Formation chert, it is not possible to demonstrate that the material was imported from central Texas where outcrops of Edwards Formation (Cretaceous) are very common. As Holliday and Welty (1981} pointed out, identical material occurs in gravel and cobble forms in the Ogallala Formation (Miocene-P~iocene), which crops out extensively along the eastern escarpment of the Llano Estacada. This material probably was derived from Cretaceous deposits that were being eroded as the Ogallala was being deposited. All excavations at Lubbock Lake prior to the LLP were carried out using feet and inches. For this reason, in this paper, linear and depth measurements pertaining to the earlier work at the site are kept in feet and inches. Lubbock Lake Project excavations were conducted in the metric system, and measurements pertaining to that work are given in that system. Measurements on lithic flakes and tools are presented in Table 3 and (Wheat 1974) was carried out using pick and shovel without screening. All recovered artifacts were plotted on a stratigraphic cross section according to geologic unit, depth below the surface, and distance from a datum. Geomys bursarius of the reservoir cut, apparently with pick, shovel, and trowel without screening, and located with reference to stratigraphic unit and a series of stations (excavation areas). Artifacts found during WTM excavations (Green 1962a; Kelley 1974) were recovered by shovels and trowels, and without screening. These excavations were within 1O-ft squares and within natural stratigraphic levels ranging from 2 to 8 in. thick. Artifacts were plotted according to depth below surface and with reference to the walls of the squares. The LLP excavations were conducted in 1-m squares and 5-cm levels within natural stratigraphic levels using trowels, brushes, and dental tools. All materials found were mapped in place with reference to the main horizontal datum, and elevations were determined using an engineer's level. Horizontal and vertical control was referenced from the same datum (Benchmark 1 ). All excavated sediment was washed through a series of finemesh screens for recovery of microcultural and microbiological materials. The WTM, WPA, and LLP excavaton units and TMM stations were located with reference to the same benchmark, although the systems employed were different. The benchmark was assigned differing arbitrary elevations by TMM and WTM work. For LLP excavations, the elevation above sea level for that benchmark was determined. Accession or catalog numbers are listed for reference indentification of specimens. Items with the accession prefix 40-36 are from Wheat's (1974) excavations; while those prefixed by 892 were recovered by Evans and Meade (Sellards 1952 ). Green's (1962a) and Kelley's (1974) material has a catalog range of TTU-A 1 through TTU-A999 and TIU-A24500 through TTU-A24963. The materials recovered by the llP are cataloged with numbers TTU-A 1000 through TTU-A?4499, TTU-A25000 through TTU-A29999, and TTU-A36000 through TTU-A49999 inclusive. The documentation and specimens from Wheat's (1974) , Green's (1962a) , and LLP excavations are housed in the Archaeology Division of The Museum, Texas Tech University, as are the specimens from Kelley's (1974) work. The materials from Evans and Meade's (Sellards 1952) work are located at the Texas Memorial Museum and Texas Archaeological Research laboratory (TARL), University of Texas.
body_text.section: Bison antiquus Lepus californicus Heterodon nasicus

body_text.text: A bison kill/butchering locale (FA4-1) is the only feature from substratum 2e. Neither lithic nor bone butchering tools were recovered, but the numerous resharpening flakes found indicate the use of several lithic tools. One major bone concentration was exposed with scattered elements and skulls around it. Subunits were noted within the concentration (Fig. 6 ).

Wheat's (1974) work yielded the only artifacts from substratum 3e. Materials were recovered from three levels within substratum 3e (Stratum H) (Tables 1, 2), all from Pit C, a 30 x 34 ft. unit excavated to a depth of 18 ft. (Wheat 1974:23) . The lowest level (WA23-1) yielded the majority of material. The features appear to reflect camping events.

During TMM explorations in the reservoir cut, elements with a recorded provenience beyond stratigraphic unit mainly came from Station E (Fig. 3 ). Based on bone preservation, at least two levels were encountered in Station E in the unit recorded as stratum 3.

One group of bones exhibits the typical white chalky appearance from leaching of stratum 3 bones. None of the located bison remains in this group showed evidence of human modification. The second, much larger group is thought to be from 4A.
At Station N (location unknown), two lithic artifacts were removed from the reservoir wall from "stratum 3, depth 2 feet" (TMM accession notes). Other associations are unknown.

Faunal material was recovered from the "friable zone" at several stations or with Stratum 3 as the only provenience data (Table  4) . The majority were from modern bison (Bison bison), none of which showed evidence of human modification. Green (1962a; Kaczor 1978) encountered materials in substratum 3 in three excavation areas (Areas 4, 5, 12) during his testing operations ( Fig. 3) . In Area 4, although Kaczor (1978:283) lumped the material under one feature designation (GA4-1), materials were recovered from two levels 16.5 em apart in depth. Due to the paucity of materials, however, the type of cultural activity occurring is undetermined.

The "upper part of stratum 3" (Kaczor 1978) in Area 5 yielded pronghorn antelope (Antilocapra americana) and modern bison remains and a lithic tool. Whether the tool was associated with the faunal remains is unknown. The pronghorn material exhibits car-nivore modification. Two horizontal concentrations of faunal material (GA 12-1) were uncovered in Area 12. One concentration was the partial remains from a pronghorn and the other the partial remains from a bison. Evidence of human modification is lacking.

During LLP excavations in Area 5, a small concentration of pronghorn antelope remains was uncovered in upper substratum 3/. This feature (FAS-9) was disturbed by the 1930s dredging, and both the wall and bones were eroding. These remains and those recovered by Green (Kaczor 1978) probably were associated. Specific carnivore markings or butchering and other human-induced modifications are lacking. It is inconclusive whether this feature primarily is the result of humans and subsequently disturbed by carnivores or solely is a carnivore event.

During TMM explorations, the vast majority of faunal remains recovered were from modern bison. Pronghorn antelope is represented by a metacarpal 892 These two units were recognized and separated by the TMM party (Evans 1948) . Evans (1949:11) described "Bed 3" as "light gray calcareous clay, porous and friable" and "Bed 4" as "calcareous sand ... pink to greenish gray in color" and also noted that "Bison bones occur locally in the lower, greenish phase." Apparently, the bone from 4A in Station E was accessioned incorrectly. Neither field drawings nor photographs of the bone bed are available, and the disposal pattern and associations of one element to another is unknown. However, the feature appears to represent another bison kill/butchering locale.

Three features were explored by the LLP. A small segment (4 m 2 ) of a larger bone bed 22 (FA5-4) in Area 5 at Station M ( Fig. 3 ) was exposed and may represent a bison kill/ butchering locale ( Fig. 7 ), although lithic material was not recovered. Most of the material was in a small concentration.
A feature (FA6-21) exposed in Area 6 ( Fig.3) contained sparse material interspersed among numerous caliche pebbles. The type of cultural activity represented is undetermined.

In Area 7 (Fig. 3) , a concentration of bison bones (FA7-1) was encountered during profiling of this segment of the reservoir wall (Trench 65). Bones removed from the wall (submitted for a radiocarbon date) and those subsequently eroded lacked evidence of human-induced modification.

Wheat (1974:20-22) divided substratum 48 into three zones, the lowermost zone being Stratum IVc. Within this bottommost section of 48 in Trench A West (Figs. 3, 5), four groupings or levels of material were recorded. Three of the levels appear to represent camping activities. The fourth grouping consists of seven lithic artifacts distributed over and slightly within the Blanco Formation clays. The artifacts are resting on the surface of these clays, buried by 48 sediments. Because of the widespread distribution over a sloped surface, these artifacts probably are not contemporaneous with each other. They were covered at various times as the valley filled. A partial second phalange (40-36-19) of an extinct horse (cf. Nannippus sp.) was recovered from within the Blanco Formation clays.

Within the middle section of 48 in Trench A West (Wheat's [1974] Stratum iVb), at least nine levels or zones of materials were encountered on the valley floor and on th.e sloping valley margin to the west These arbitrary levels were determined by stratigraphic position and elevation. This number was arrived at by a combination of clustered materials, materials along the two contacts (IVc/IVb and iVb/IVa), and 10-in. arbitrary levels in the sediments between the two contacts (70 in. = 7 zones) in the valley floor (units 0-205). Upslope (units 205-240) as the deposit thinned, these internal seven zones were compressed into two. lithics are the primary material and again appear to represent accumulated debris from numerous camping events. Joint explorations by Green (1962a) and Kelley (1974) yielded a few items, probably the result of camping activities. In Area 7 ( Fig.  3 ), GA7-8 produced one lithic and other unidentified material. Explorations in Area 8 ( Fig. 3 ) yielded six lithics from within an 8-cm level of one excavation block.
