A rock-covered baking oven (FA16-1) was located in substratum 48 (middle of Wheat's [1974] Stratum IVb) during llP explorations in Area 16 (Fig. 8 ). This oven is ca. 25 m north of Wheat's (1974) Trench A West between units 120 and 160. Only an area large enough to expose and recover the oven was opened. The activity floor associated with it was not excavated. Two radiocarbon determinations were obtained on very fine ash and organic matter:4700 ± 65years8.P.,SI-4171;4960 23 ± 50 years B.P., SMU-492 (Holliday et al. 1983) .

Material was recovered from the A horizon of the lubbock lake Soil during excavations by Wheat (1974) , Green (1962a) , Kelley (1974) , and the lLP. Wheat (1974:21) designated the A horizon as Stratum 5. Occupational features located within the A horizon cannot be correlated between the various excavation areas based on their position relative to pedologic boundaries because such boundaries cannot be used as stratigraphic indicators. The thickness of the A horizon varies throughout the landmark, and that thickness does not have stratigraphic significance.

During WPA excavations, little work was done in stratum 4 in Trench A East because of the high water table which was encountered in the A horizon of the Lubbock Lake Soil. Wheat (1939: "heavier and darker than the bones coming from the sand above." The bison elements, a femoral head and distal end of a radius (40-36-137), are organically stained, chemically weathered, and heavily eroded. They constitute the only material recovered in stratum 4 in Trench A East. In Trench A West, Wheat (1974) encountered at least seven zones of material based on stratigraphic position and elevation. The number was arrived at in the same manner as for the zones within his Stratum IVb. Material from the lowermost zone may be in situ and not mixed, but artifacts from the other six zones include a mixture of Archaic and post-Archaic materials. Primarily lithic material, which appears to represent various camping events, was recovered. Green (1962a) uncovered a small concentration of modern bison remains in Area 7 (GA7-7) at the bottom of the A horizon. The material exhibits human-induced modification and may represent a bison kill/butchering locale. Three levels of occupational debris were encountered during Green's (1962a) and Kelley's (1974) concordant explorations in Area 8 (Fig. 3) . The scattered material and hearthstones indicate several camping events.

The LLP explorations into the A horizon of the Lubbock Lake Soil have been minimal and restricted to Area 8. A single 1-m test unit was excavated 28 em into the more than 40-cm A horizon in Area 8. Two levels of material were recovered, one in the top 3 em of the A horizon and the second from the last 5 em of excavations. This material may reflect camping activities.

Two Late Archaic projectile points were recovered, one during stratigraphic trenching in substratum 4B and the other from a protohistoric feature. Numerous modern bison elements were recovered during TMM investigations into stratum 4, and most are recorded with only that general designation. All remains that could be located were examined for cultural modification, and only one exhibited direct evidence of such. Three lithic artifacts were recovered from stratum 4, but currently a more exact placement in a substratum or determination of whether they were associated with faunal materials is not possible.

Based on the number of skulls recovered, three bison are represented in the exposed section of FA4-1 ( Fig. 6 ). One individual is an adult male, represented by an edentulous skull (TTU-A2299) and right humerus (TTU-A 14050). The fused proximal end of the humerus indicates an animal older than six years.

The second skull (TTU-A2300) is that of an adult female. The permanent maxillary teeth are erupted and in wear. Both mandibles were recovered. Mandibular width measures 71.0 mm for the right mandible (TTU-A2407) and 72.0 mm for the left (TTU-A2380). The permanent teeth are erupted and in wear, aging the animal to the 5.6 to 11.0 year group. Based on element size, the post-cranial adult remains are female, and the fused epiphyses indicate that she was older than six years.

A smashed skull (TTU-A14151, 14155, 14160) is from a subadult. The maxillae (TTU-A 14155, 14160) and a left mandible (TTU-A2302) were recovered. Dental eruption and tooth row wear of the mandible ages the subadult between 2.6 and 3 years. The maxillae fall in the 2.6 year age category. Mandibular width measurement is 75.0 mm. This measurement is larger than that of the adult female, and considering the age, this subadult probably is a male.

The near articulation of the units and completeness of vertebrae indicate incomplete processing. However, hump muscles were removed as each thoracic vertebra has a blow depression at the base of the spine.

Over 115 resharpening flakes and debitage were recovered. Material sources indicate the use of at least eight tools from cherts of Edwards Formation, Potter, and an unknown source; Alibates agate; Tecovas jasper; chalcedony; quartzite; and silicified caliche.

Wheat's (1974) lowest level (WA23-1) consisted of both bone and lithics. Artifact 40-36-128 is a segment of diaphyseal compact bone lacking the cortical surface. Due to the thickness of the compact bone, it prob-ably is from bison. Five bones (40-36-135) are modern bison and include a left patella, right proximal anterolateral metacarpal segment, small diaphyseal segment from a radius or tibia, and the head and tubercle of a rib. The diaphyseal segment exhibits a helical fracture, the juncture of intersecting fracture fronts, and hackle marks along the exposed compact bone surface. Provenience on three bison phalanges (40-36-138) is not recorded. However, based on their condition and the general preservation state of substratum 3e bones, these phalanges are considered to have come from substratum 3e and probably are associated with W A23-1 .

Lithic material from the lowest level consists of two tools, both from Edwards Formation chert, and a missing "Flint chip" (40-36-124). Specimen 40-36-44 is a broken uniface ( Fig. 9a ). The unbroken edge exhibits steep retouch and utilization flaking. Specimen 40-36-98 is a broken biface with a plano- convex cross section (Fig. 9b ). The convex dorsal side exhibits flaking across the surface, with steep angle retouch and utilization flaking and crushing along the three edges. Projections are worn and rounded. Material from WA23-2 consists of a retouched core segment (40-36-99) from an apparently heat-treated cobble (fractured internal structure) of Edwards Formation chert (Fig. 9c ). Shallow-angle retouch occurs along the dorsal right lateral with bifacial utilization flaking. Utilization flaking occurs along the ventral left lateral. This side forms a right angle with the dorsal surface. Utilization flaking also occurs along the ventral distal end. All these edges are worn.

Material from WA23-3 consists of a quartzite uniface (40-36-122) . It is retouched along the dorsal left proximal lateral. Utilization flaking and worn, rounded edges and projections occur along this edge and the right distal lateral and apex. The apex exhibits dorsal hinge flaking and ventral edge rounding (Fig.  9d ).

From the TMM work at Station N, Artifact 892-144 (Edwards Formation chert) is a retouched flake that exhibits steep retouch on the dorsal side along the right lateral and distal end (Fig. 9e ). Utilization flaking occurs along the dorsal distal end and adjacent corners. Artifact 892-145 (Edwards Formation chert) is a retouched flake that exhibits steep retouch on the dorsal side along the right and left laterals and distal end ( Fig. 9f ). Intense use scarring (step fracturing, utilization flaking, worn projections, and rounded edges) occurs along these three sides. The tool may have been hafted, as the edges are smoothed on the right lateral for 17 mm.and left lateral for 13 mm above the proximal end. Bifacial flaking occurs on the proximal end, apparently to thin the bulbar area.

In Green's (1962a; Kaczor 1978) work in Area 4, the lower level of GA4-1 produced a chunk of burned silicified caliche (TTU-A989) and the partial skull (TTU-A985) of Cratogeomys castenops (mexican pocket gopher). The upper level of GA4-1 produced two chunks (TTU-A981, TIU-A986) of burned silicified caliche and a utilized flake (TIU-A984). The flake (fine-grained quartzite) ex-hibits bifacial utilization flaking along the laterals and distal end. Fauna! remains include the tubercle section (TTU-A988) of a bison rib, the left astragalus (TTU-A987) of a coyote, and a partial left patella (TTU-A982) from a medium-sized artiodactyl.

In Area 12 (GA12-1), butchering damage is lacking on the pronghorn remains, but carnivore tooth scoring, excavation damage, and preparator marks are evident The bison material is weathered. Horizontal tension failure from weathering or ground compression produced rectilinear fracturing of the vertebral spine (TTU-A806) and rib (TTU-A793). Preparator marks are evident on the bison remains, but carnivore or butchering damage is lacking.

Blacktai! jackrabbit (Lepus califoricus) is represented by the distal end of a humerus (TTU-A954) and coyote by the proximal end of a left tibia (TTU-A813) and a phalange (TIU-A22438). A mud turtle (Kinosternon f!avescens) and ornate box turtle (Terrapene ornata) are represented by carapace sections (TTU-A805, TTU-A807, TTU-A808, TTU-A814). None of these remains show evidence of butchering, although jackrabbit, coyote, and box turtle were food sources during the Paleo-Indian period (Johnson 1977 ; E. Hughes 1984) . Green's (1962a; Kaczor 1978) The faunal material was recovered at the same elevation within the same excavation block; the flake comes from another excavation block at an unrecorded elevation. None of the material was plotted (Kaczor 1978:69) . The medial and lateral epicondyles of the femur exhibit carnivore tooth punctures and abrasion; tooth scoring occurs along the medial anterior diaphysis below the fractured surface. The fracture surface was exposed through horizontal tension failure and exhibits split line interference (Johnson 1985) . Butchering evidence and other human-induced modifications are lacking.

The LLP Area 5 excavations in this sub-stratum (FA5-9) uncovered additional pronghorn material consisting of the lower spinal column in articular position (TTU-A 11805-11811), disarticulated vertebrae (TTU-A11812-i1818), and the right ilium (TTU-A11819). The left ilium (TTU-A11820), a thoracic vertebra (TTU-A1513), and a rib segment (TTU-A1512) were recovered after eroding from the bone concentration. The bones are chemically weathered. Vertebral spines and processes were removed or comminuted.
Stratum 4 -Substratum 4A

The TMM bone bed at Station E yielded a MN! equalling 10 bison (seven adults, three subadults) based on post-cranial and mandibular material. Post-cranially, only eight animals are represented. This count is repeatable based on astragali, calcanei, metacarpals, metatarsals, and femora. Other major skeletal elements are represented, which suggests whole carcasses being present. The eight bison break down into seven adults and one subadult (unfused epiphyses and very small size). Based on consistent size differences, the adults appear to represent three males and four females.

Of the seven mandibles located (five rights, two lefts), those that could be measured represent two males {892-4E Three of the bison elements exhibit cut lines from lithic tools during the butchering operation. Mandible 892-3E [16] has a set of cut lines on the lower exterior border below dP .4-M 1 • This damage most likely was inflicted during skinning. A femur (892-3E) exhibits a set of cut lines on the anterior shaft below the head, which probably occurred during defleshing. A metacarpal (892-3E) has two sets of cut lines on the left anterior shaft. The proximal set consists of two long parallel lines with two short parallel lines between them. The set is oriented diagonally (right to left) to the long axis of the bone. The middiaphysis set consists of one linear mark oriented diagonally (left to right) to the long axis of the-bone ( Fig. 1 Oa) . These actions could occur either during defleshing or tendon removal. The only indication of marrow processing is a long bone segment (892-479) that exhibits helical fracture surfaces. Carnivore damage is lacking on the bones.

A bison left tibia (892-304) is accessioned from the "top of green sand zone" (substratum 4A), "west side of reservoir." It ex-hibits two sets of cut lines on the distal anterior shaft beside and on the tibial crest (Fig. 1 Ob) . Each set consists of numerous parallel lines oriented diagonally (right to left) to the long axis of the bone. The element was further modified through dynamic loading (striking a forceful, well-directed blow) which opened the shaft and exposed the marrow cavity. The fracture surface exhibits hackle marks (Fig. 10b) . The preserved impact area and apparent rebound impact indicate a single anvil mode with the element being positioned on its lateral and the blow delivered to the lower third of the medial diaphysis.

The LLP work (Area 5) at Station M in substratum 4A uncovered a small concentration of bison remains (FA5-4; Fig. 7 ) that included a radius, ulna, metacarpals, tibia, tarsals, phalanges, and ribs. Based on size and epiphyseal union, the bison (Bison bison) was an adult female of 6 years or older. A diaphyseal segment of the distal end of a tibia (TTU-A8198) exhibits helical fracture surfaces and a preserved impact point. It lacks carnivore markings, as do the other elements.

Faunal remains from FA6-21 are from modern bison, coyote, mexican pocket gopher, and white-throated woodrat (Neotoma albigula). These remains lack evidence of human modification. Lithic material includes the midsection from a biface (TTU-A28954) and a small resharpening flake (TIU-A28957; translucent chert). The biface (chert of unknown source) is lenticular in cross section (Fig. 11 a) . It exhibits parallel flaking within the Sudplano tradition (Knudson 1983a (Knudson , 1983b and may be a broken Paleo-Indian point that had been picked up by later Archaic peoples or redeposited.

During Wheat's (1974) work in Trench A West (Figs. 3, 5 ), seven lithic artifacts were recovered widely distributed over the sloping Blanco Formation clays. Three well-worn flake unifaces were found on the undulating, eroded upland surface of the Blanco Formation. Artifact 40-36-16 (Edwards Formation chert) is a keeled scraper with steep retouch along the laterals and distal end (Fig. 11 b) . An unfaceted platform and pronounced bulb that was flattened by flake removal are present. Intense utilization flaking occurs from mid-laterals to around the distal end. Artifacts 40-36-15 ( Fig. 11 c) and 40-36-17 ( Fig. 11 d) were found about 8ft. apart and about 67 to 75 ft. from specimen 40-36-16. Artifact 40-36-15 (Tecovas jasper) exhibits steep-angle retouch along laterals and distal end with intensive utilization flaking occurring along these edges. The proximal end of the flake is broken. Artifact 40-36-17 (Edwards Formation chert) is another keeled scraper of steep retouch along ali four sides and has intensive utilization flaking. The platform and bulb were removed in the retouching process.

Artifacts 40-36-89 and 40-36-90 were recovered about 2 ft. apart and 20 ft. from specimen 40-36-17, along the sloping contact with the Blanco Formation. Artifact 40-36-89 (Edwards Formation chert) is the distal end of a utilized f!ake. Utilization flaking occurs bifacially on the laterals, on the dorsal distal end, and on the edge of the broken surface perpendicular to the left dorsal surface. The left distal dorsal corner is worn and utilized around a projection. Artifact 40-36-90 (Edwards Formation chert) is a utilized hinge flake. Utilization flaking occurs on the dorsal mid-lateral. The platform is multifaceted, and the flake has a diffuse bulb.

Artifact 40-36-116 was found about 24 ft. downslope from specimen 40-36-90. It is a rectangular flake (Edwards Formation chert) with a crushed platform. Artifact 40-36-1 i 8 was found within 5 ft. upslope from specimen 40-36-116. Although now missing, it was accessioned as "Flint," and Kelley (1 974:68) described it as a side or end scraper.

Twelve lithic artifacts were recovered from the bottommost 48 sediments at the contact of substrata 3e and 48. A cluster of nine artifacts (WA23-4) within about 8 ft. of each other was located in the same 1O-ft. unit (21 0-220) of Trench A West. Artifact 40-36-117 (Edwards Formation chert) is a utilized hinge flake exhibiting bifacial use wear along both laterals. The flake has a multifaceted, lipped platform and a diffuse bulb. Artifacts 40-36-105 are utilized flakes (Edwards Formation chert), one exhibiting use wear along both dorsal laterals and the other on the dorsal right lateral and ventral left lateral. Both have multifaceted, lipped platforms and diffuse bulbs.

Artifact 40-36-120 (Aiibates agate) is the midsection of a large uniface (Fig. 12a) . One lateral exhibits steep-angle retouch, with retouch on the other lateral at a shallower angle. Intensive utilization flaking and crushing occur along the entire length of both laterals. Artifacts 40-36-126 and 40-36-113 are from Edwards Formation chert. Artifact 40-36-126 ( Fig. 12b) is a broken uniface exhibiting steepangle retouch and utilization flaking along the dorsal left lateral. Artifact 40-36-i 13 (Fig. 12c) is an alternately beveled biface made on an expanding flake that still exhibits the platform (unfaceted).

Artifact 40-36-115 (Edwards Formation chert) is a retouched expanding flake (Fig.  12d) . Steep-angle retouch and use wear occur along the dorsal right lateral and distal end. The flake exhibits an unfaceted platform, and the pronounced bulb was thinned by the removal of two large flakes from the left edge. Artifact 40-36-112, now missing, was accessioned as "Flint," measured by Wheat (1974: 35) , and described and illustrated by Kelley (1974:68-69, Fig. 80 ) as a scraper. Artifact 40-36-1 00 (Edwards Formation chert) is a broken retouched flake (Fig. 12e) . Steep retouch and utilization flaking occur along both dorsal laterals. Artifact 40-36-111 , now missing, was accessioned as a "Scraper-'spokeshave."' It was measured and described by Wheat (1974:32) and illustrated by Kelley (1974:69, Fig. 8B) .

A second cluster (WA23-5) was located in the same stratigraphic position about 1 0 ft. downslope (units 200-210) from WA23-4. Artifact 40-36-114 (Edwards Formation chert) is a broken retouched flake (Fig. 12f) . Steep retouch and use wear occur along the dorsal right lateral, and intensive utilization and crushing along the ventral distal end. Artifact 40-36-101 (Edwards Formation chert) is another retouched flake (Fig. 12g) . A series of thinning flakes was removed ventrally at both the proximal and distal ends. The platform was obliterated and the dorsal proximal end steeply retouched. Use wear occurs along the two ends and left lateral. The entire right lateral is covered by cortex. Artifact 40-36-1 08 is a piece of schist. Artifact 40-36-107, now missing, was accessioned as "Flint."

The third level of materials was well above the stratigraphic contact of 4B and 3e or Blanco Formation and the fourth one near the top of Wheat's (1974) Stratum IVc. The lower level (WA23-6) followed the sloping topography and consisted of four lithic artifacts and two teeth spaced over a five-unit block (50 ft.). Artifact 40-36-123 (Edwards Formation chert) is a utilized contracting flake. Utilization flaking occurs along the ventral right lateral. The platform is broken off, and a hinge flake removed the bulb. Artifact 40-36-1 03 is a right M 3 from a modern bison. The tooth was fully erupted and all cusps in wear, representing an animal greater than 5.5 years. Artifact 40-36-106 is a segment of a molar from a modern bison.

Artifact 40-36-104 (Aiibates agate) is a broken, unused uniface exhibiting steep retouch (Fig. 13a) . Artifact 40-36-102 (Edwards Formation chert) is a well-utilized flake that has been classified as a graver (Wheat 1974:34; Kelley 1974:56) . The flake has a multifaceted, lipped platform with a diffuse bulb. Utilization flaking occurs along the distal end around two projections (Fig. 13b) . Artifact 40-36-91 (Edwards Formation chert) is an unmodified, rectangular flake that has a multifaceted, lipped platform and a diffuse bulb.

The upper level of material consisted of two groupings of seven lithic artifacts dis-tributed over the sloping landscape. The valley floor grouping (WA23-7) has the most integrity of the two groupings and a lineal extent of about 70 ft. Artifacts 40-36-4 are a biface and a small chunk of chert (source unknown). Although the biface now is missing (accessioned as a "Quartz knife"), it was described, measured, and illustrated by Wheat (1974:28, 31) and Kelley (1974:58) . Artifact 40-36-125 is a split and broken quartzite cobble that appears to have one large flake removed to form an edge. Utilization flaking occurs along that edge. Artifact 40-36-110 (Tecovas quartzite) is a broken biface (Fig. 13c ) that is lenticular in cross section. Utilization flaking and crushing occur along the edges on opposite sides. Artifact 40-36-121 is a small chunk of Alibates agate.

The slope grouping (WA23-8) has a lineal extent of 27ft., and depths vary due to the sloping topography. However, Wheat's (1974: 20) IVc (4B) comes to the surface where artifact 40-36-92 was discovered (6 in. from the surface), and it may or may not be associated with the other materials which are overlain by additional 4B sediments (Wheat's [1974] Strata IVb and IVa) and stratum 5.

Artifact 40-36-85 (Edwards Formation chert) is a steeply, alternately retouched flake (Fig. 13d) . The platform is crushed, and the removal of a large flake has flattened the bulbar area. The tool is heavily worn. The distal left corner forms a projection that is bounded on the left by a dorsally retouched edge and on the right by a small notch with utilization flaking. The adjacent distal edge exhibits minute ventral utilization flaking. Both the dorsal retouched and ventral utilized edge exhibit well worn and rounded edges and use polish that extends 3.5 mm back from the edge. Both Wheat (1974:34) and Kelley (197 4:56) interpreted this tool as a graver.

Artifact 40-36-57 (Edwards Formation chert) is the broken edge of a steeply retouched uniface (Fig. 13e) . Bifacial utilization occurs along the edge with crushing on the dorsal side and striations on the flat ventral surface. Artifact 40-36-92 is a smaller version of artifact 40-36-125. Wheat (1974:37) listed it as an unmodified primary flake and measured it. (1974:20) Stratum IVc. The two artifacts were accessioned as "Pottery." Although plotted but not discussed by Wheat {1974:20), Kelley {1974:56) identified one artifact as a sherd of Chupadero Black-on-White. She also noted that the sherd was found close to a retouched flake (given the same accession number but not noted on the accession card). Both artifacts now are missing. This material demonstrates the cultural mixing possible where 4B sediments form the more recent surface.

At least nine zones of material occur within the middle section of 4B (Stratum IVb) in Wheat's (1974) Trench A West (Figs. 3, 5) . Material in WA23-9 (bottom contact IVc/IVb) occurs along the slope. Artifact 40-36-45 (Edwards Formation chert) is the distal end of a utilized flake that exhibits bifacial utilization along the remaining edges. The utilized flake was subjected to intense heat as it bears two pot lids on its dorsal surface and a fractured internal structure. Artifact 40-36-77 (Tecovas jasper) is the distal end of a utilized flake that exhibits utilization along the remaining right lateral. Artifact 40-36-59 is the distal end of a left tibia from a modern bison. It is highly weathered, and the cortical surface is too eroded to determine if cut lines are present. Fracture agency cannot be determined because the fracture surfaces are too eroded and other identifying characters not preserved. Artifact 40-36-42 (Edwards Formation chert) is a small chunk •Of chert that exhibits a fractured internal structure.

Two isolated lithics comprise the first valley floor zone above the bottom contact. The lithics had a lineal extent of ca. 67ft. but were within an inch of each other in depth. Artifact 40-36-43 (Tecovas quartzite) is the distal end of a flake, while artifact 40-36-83 (translucent chert) is a piece of debitage.

The second valley floor zone (WA23-10) has a lineal extent of ca. 77ft. within an 8 in. depth range. Artifact 40-36-41 was accessioned as "Flint chips," but one flake (silicified caliche) remains in the collection. It is unmodified and has a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifact 40-36-94 is the left M 2 of a modern bison. Artifact 40-36-76 (Edwards Formation chert) is a broken utilized flake. Utilization scarring occurs on the dorsal right lateral adjacent to the break. The expanding flake has a multifaceted, lipped platform with a diffuse bulb. Artifact 40-36-95 (translucent chert) is an unmodified, contracting flake with an unfaceted platform and large eraillure scar that removed the bulb. Artifact 40-36-82 (Edwards Formation chert) is the distal end of a broken utilized flake. Bifacial utilization occurs along the distal right lateral. Artifact 40-36-86 (Edwards Formation chert) is an unmodified, broken square flake with a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb.

Two clusters of material ca. 68 ft. apart occur in the third valley floor zone which has a lineal extent of ca. 71 ft. Artifacts 40-36-30 and 40-36-56 were located within 2.5 ft. of each other (WA23-11). Artifact 40-36-30 (Edwards Formation chert) is an expanding utilized flake with a multifaceted, lipped platform and a diffuse bulb. Ventral utilization scarring occurs along the right lateral, while scarring along the left lateral is dorsal. Artifact 40-36-56 is a base of a projectile point with an expanded convex stem. Wheat (197 4:30) classified it as a Trinity point, and Kelley (1974:69, Fig. 80 ) illustrated it.

The second cluster (WA23-12) is composed of three artifacts found within 1.5 ft. of each other. Artifact 40-36-47 (Edwards Formation chert) is a utilized flake that exhibits utilization flaking along the dorsal right lateral. The expanding flake has a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifact 40-36-84 (Edwards Formation chert) is an unmodified, expanding flake with a lipped, multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifact 40-36-54 (obsidian) is a contracting utilized flake with a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Cortex occurs along the right dorsal edge, while utilization scarring is along the right ventral edge.

Two clusters and two isolated specimens comprise the fourth valley floor zone over a lineal extent of ca. 43 ft. The first cluster (WA23-13) consisted of six small lithic flakes and debitage found within 8 in. of each other and 1 in. depth range. Artifact 40-36-55 is a piece of broken quartzite debitage. Artifacts 40-36-71 are two unmodified flakes and three pieces of broken debitage (quartzite, Alibates agate, and a chert of unknown source). The expanding, hinge flake (Edwards Formation chert) has a lipped, multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb; the square flake (Tecovas jasper) has a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb.
Isolated artifact 40-36-51 is a piece of debitage (Aiibates agate). It was located 23 ft. further west of the first cluster and 9ft. from the second cluster.

The second cluster (WA23-14) consisted of a hearth with associated hearthstones and two pieces of unburned bone from about a foot away. The six hearthstones (40-36-133) are broken and burned pieces of sandstone. Artifact 40-36-74 is a broken bison rib that is weathered. Much of the cortex has been removed from one side. Artifact 40-36-79 is a weathered, small shaft segment from a large mammal.

Isolated artifact 40-36-75 (Edwards Formation chert) is the distal end of a utilized flake. Utilization scarring occurs along the entire dorsal right and left laterals and ventral distal end. It was located ca. 10 ft. further west of the second cluster.

Three lithics and a tiny piece of burned bone were located in the fifth valley floor zone (WA23-15) within a lineal extent of ca. 67ft. The burned bone (40-36-70) had been accessioned as charcoal. Artifacts 40-36-3 and 40-36-46 were found within 6 in. of each other and 4 in. difference in depth. Artifact 40-36-3 (Edwards Formation chert) is a bifacially flaked T-shaped drill (Fig. 14a) . The drill bit is alternately beveled. Artifact 40-36-46 (Edwards Formation chert) is a broken utilized flake that exhibits utilization scarring along the dorsal left lateral and at the right distolateral corner. The flake has a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifact 40-36-80 (Edwards Formation chert) is a wedge section from a uniface that exhibits intensive crushing and flaking of the edge.

Two pieces of burned large mammal skull sections (40-36-131) were recovered from the sixth valley floor zone, while only one lithic was located in the seventh zone. Artifact Fig. 14. Substratum 48 lithic tools: a, b, c, d, e, f, 40-36-9 (Edwards Formation chert) is a steeply retouched flake uniface (Fig. 14b ) with intensive wear crushing and flaking along the distal end. The laterals were alternately flaked. The expanding flake has a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb.

Two lithics were recovered within the first slope zone 0fV A23-16). Artifacts 40-36-68 (Edwards Formation chert) and 40-36-8 (Edwards Formation chert) were within a foot of each other at the same depth. The former is a piece of debitage; the latter is a flake uniface steeply retouched and exhibiting utilization flaking and crushing along the edges (Fig.  14c) . The flake has a multifaceted platform, and the bulbar area was thinned by removal of two flakes from the proximal end.

The second slope zone (WA23-17) consisted of three lithics found within a lineal extent of ca. 22 ft. Artifact 40-36-69 (translucent chert) is an unmodified, expanding flake that has a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifact 40-36-78 (Edwards Formation chert) is a utilized split flake with a crushed platform and diffuse bulb. Utilization scarring occurs along the dorsal right lateral. Artifact 40-36-64 is an unmodified, expanding flake (purple quartzite).

Material from Wheat's (1974) upper contact (IVb/IVa) occurs along a lineal extent of ca. 224ft. Wheat (1974:27) encountered another hearth (W A23-18) composed of "blackened rocks and caliche lumps." Artifact 40-36-36 consists of four hearthstones (burned caliche nodules) saved from this hearth.
Wheat (1974:27) noted that a utilized flake found with the hearth received the same accession number. Kelley (1974:69, Fig. 8E ) illustrated it, but the flake now is missing.

A third hearth (WA23-"19) was encountered 13 ft. further west but apparently was vandalized before it could be recorded. Artifact 40-36-66 apparently was associated with this hearth (Wheat 1974:27) . Although recorded as a bison tibia (Wheat 1974:27) , artifact 40-36-66 is the distal end of a bison metatarsal. It exhibits an impact and cone flake scar on the posteromedial side and a helical fracture surface. A single anvil mode was used, with the element positioned on its lateral side. A set of parallel cut lines occurs on the posterior diaphysis below the fracture surface at a diagonal (left to right) to the long axis of the bone (Fig. 15) .
Isolated artifact 40-36-6 is a Bulverde point (Edwards Formation chert). It was broken and reworked ( Fig. 14d) .

Artifacts 40-36-81, 40-36-63 , and 40-36-93 were found within 7ft. of each other 0JVA23-20). Artifact 40-36-81 (Potter chert) is an unmodified, expanding flake with an unfaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifact 40-36-63 (translucent chert) is a broken flake uniface with steep-angle retouch and utilization flaking along the dorsal right lateral (Fig. 14e) . The flake has an unfaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifact 40-36-93 (Edwards Formation chert) is a utilized flake with utilization flaking along the ventral left lateral. The flake has a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb.

Isolated artifact 40-36-13 (Edwards Formation chert) is a steeply retouched flake uniface (Fig. 14f) . Cortex covers the platform and most of the left lateral. Retouch occurs from the left distolateral around to the right proximolateral. Intensive utilization crushing and flaking occur along the distal end with bifacial utilization flaking along the right lateral.

In Area 7 (Fig. 3) , work by Green (1962a) in substratum 48 (GA7-8) produced artifact TIU-A22431, a rectangular cortex flake (Edwards Formation chert) that exhibits utilization flaking along the distal end. The flake has a pronounced bulb and unfaceted platform that exhibits some crushing. Kaczor (1978: 277} noted that the other items from this feature were missing from the collection. Explorations in Area 8 (Green 1962a; Kelley 1974) in this substratum yielded a chunk of purple quartzite (TTU-A24841 ), four chunks of burned silicified caliche (TrU-A24840), and a piece of lithic debitage (TTU-A24857; Edwards Formation chert).

The LLP oven (FA16-1) in substratum 48 had a burned, hardened outline of a pit that was ovoid, approximately i m across and 40 em deep (Fig. 8) . The oven interior was filled with ash. The oval pit was covered with burned caliche cobbles capping the pit; hence, the designation as a baking oven. A broken, worn sandstone metate (TTU-A3458) was found in the rock covering. One tiny lithic resharpening flake (TTU-A22125; Edwards Formation chert) and five unburned bison bones (TTU-A3390, TTU-A22126-22129) were found in the fill among the cobbles. This material probably represents post-use deposition. The bones are highly weathered and root-etched. Metapodial condyles TTU-A3390 are highly pitted and comminuted with much of the cortical surface removed. Rib shaft TIU-A22129 bears two small pits that may be the weathered remains of carnivore tooth punctures.

During Wheat's (1974) work, the lowermost zone of cultural material in the A horizon of the lubbock lake Soil in Trench A West produced one lithic. Artifact 40-36-23 (translucent chert) is a steeply retouched, contracting flake. It is alternately retouched along the sides and retouched along the left dorsal proximolateral (Fig. 16a) . Utilization flaking occurs along ail edges. The distal apex forms a projection that exhibits utilization wear on both sides. The second zone produced a sherd of Chupadero Black-on-White (40-36-'7; Wheat 1974:28, Fig. 2A ). Also accessioned under the same number was a "fragment flint" which is now missing.

Four isolated artifacts were recovered in the third zone within a lineal extent of ca. 103 fl. Artifact 40-36-21 is a chw:Jk of milky quartzite cobble that has been bifacially flaked to create an edge which exhibits some edge crushing. Artifacts 40-36-26 and 40-36-96 are expanding flakes (Edwards Formation chert) with lipped, faceted platforms and diffuse bulbs. The former exhibits utilization flaking along the dorsal right distolateral, and the latter is unmodified. Artifact 40-36-52 is the right P 3 (highly worn) from a modern bison.

Five artifacts in the fourth zone were spaced over a lineal extent of ca. 123 ft. Artifact 40-36-87 is an unmodified, expanding flake (Edwards Formation chert) with a lipped, unfaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifacts 40-36-62 consist of three small fragments of burned mammal bone. Artifacts 40-36-60 and 40-36-53 are unmodified flakes with faceted platforms. The former (Edwards Formation chert) is an expanding flake with a pronounced bulb; the latter (Potter chert) is a square flake with a diffuse bulb. Artifact 40-36-67 is a broken biface (Edwards Formation chert) that does not exhibit wear (Fig. 16b) .

The fifth zone produced a segment of a bison mandible (40-36-49) and a piece of debitage (40-36-88) from Edwards Formation chert. These materials were found ca. 36 ft. apart. The mandible segment is the lower ramus section that encompasses the P 2 -M 2 tooth row; M 1 and P 4 remain in their sockets. The P 4 is heavily worn and dished, while M 1 was in regular wear. The lower border was removed, and a blow depression is preserved below the P 2 socket. The mandible is weathered.

Artifacts 40-36-73 and 40-36-40 0NA23-21) were found in the sixth zone within a foot of each other and in 1 in. depth range. Artifact 40-36-73 (Edwards Formation chert) is the broken edge of a uniface that exhibits some utilization flaking at a corner. Artifact 40-36-40 (Potter chert) is a primary, ovoid flake. with an unfaceted platform and protruding bulb. Accession cards for both these artifacts list "Flint chips," but only one artifact per accession number was located in the collection. Green (1962a) uncovered in Area 7 a small concentration of material (GA7-7) at the bottom of the A horizon of the Lubbock Lake Soil. The material represents part of the lower back right leg of a young bison (less than 4.5 years old), consisting of the patella (TIU-A22425), distal tibial epiphyseal plate {TIU-A22427), astragalus (TTU-A22425), cubonavicular (TIU-A22425), calcaneum (TIU-A22424), first phalange (TTU-A22429), and 10 radial diaphyseal segments of the tibia (TIU-A22425, TIU-A22428, TTU-A22430). The tibia had been opened through dynamic loading. Fracture surfaces exhibit intersecting fracture fronts and hackle marks. One segment (TTU-A22425) preserves the impact area that exhibits flake scarring and crushing from three blows delivered to open the shaft. The tarsals, phalange, and tibial epiphyseal plate are chemically weathered, with the cortical surface appearing fibrous. A chunk of burned silicified caliche (TIU-A22426) was associated with the bison material.

During Green's (1962a) and Kelley's (1974) work in Area 8, three occupation levels were encountered. The lowermost level (GA8-11, KA8-12) consisted primarily of scattered hearthstones, all chunks of burned silicified caliche (N = 61), and lithic debris (N = 15). Artifact TTU-A781 (white chert of unknown source) is the midsection of a retouched flake. Retouch and utilization scarring occur along both dorsal laterals. Artifact TIU-A767 (Edwards Formation chert) is an unmodified, contracting flake with an unfaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Cortex covers the platform. Artifacts TTU-A771 (Edwards Formation chert) are unmodified flakes with diffuse bulbs. One is a contracting cortex flake with a crushed platform; the other is an expanding tertiary hinge flake with multifaceted platform. Six tiny resharpening flakes (TIU-A771, TIU-A777; Edwards Formation chert) and five pieces of debitage (TIU-A771, TIU-A779, Edwards Formation chert; TTU-A779, Tecovas jasper) also were recovered. Associated with this material were fragments of burned bone (N = 15) and a highly eroded, chemically weathered bison right lunar (TTU-A768).

The middle level (KA8-11) yielded lithic flakes and debitage (N = 5), a segment of a bison humeral condyle (TIU-A24848), bone fragments (N = 4), and scattered chunks of burned silicified caliche (N = 7). Artifact TIU-A24832 (black chert of unknown source) is a broken, utilized flake, with utilization scarring along the left dorsal midlateral. Artifacts TIU-A24822 (Edwards Formation chert) and TIU-A24843 (silicified caliche) are expanding flakes with unfaceted platforms. The former has a diffuse bulb, while the latter has a pronounced one. Artifact TIU-A24830 (Edwards Formation chert) is a broken flake with a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb, while artifact TIU-A24831 (Edwards Formation chert) is a tiny resharpening flake. The uppermost level (GA8-10, KA8-10) uncovered in the A horizon yielded highly eroded and weather-fractured bison bones(N = 6) and fragments (N = 14) and scattered chunks (N = 1 0) of burned silicified caliche.
The bison elements include the left mediaproximal end of a radius (TIU-A24854), right capitate-trapezium (TIU-A746), metapodial condyle (TIU-A750), rib shaft (TTU-A751), and scapula blade (TIU-A744).

Two levels of material in the A horizon of the Lubbock Lake Soil in Area 8 were encountered by LLP explorations.-The first level (FA8-15) yielded a broken utilized flake (TIU-A5996) and knapping debris (N = 1 ), both from Edwards Formation chert. The utilized flake exhibits alternate bifacial use scarring along the left lateral.

The second level (FA8-14) yielded three utilized flakes (N = 3) and knapping debris (N = 16). Artifact TTU-A6437 (Edwards Formation chert) exhibits alternate utilization flaking along the laterals. It is an expanding flake with a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifact TTU-A6436 (translucent chert) has utilization flaking along the dorsal right lateral and cortex along the left lateral. It is an expanding flake with a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Artifact TTU-A6471 (white chert of unknown source) is a broken segment that exhibits utilization flaking along the edge. The knapping debris mainly is from Edwards Formation chert.

The Late Archaic projectile points recovered by LLP include Ellis and Marcos. The Ellis point (TTU-A22189; translucent, pinkish-gray chert) was recovered during stratigraphic trenching in substratum 4B, Trench 83. The blade was reworked to form a new tip, and the stem is slightly expanding with a straight base (Fig. 16c) .

The Marcos point (TTU-A 12325; Edwards Formation chert) was recovered from a protohistoric feature. It was broken and subsequently reworked, giving it an asymmetrical shape (Fig. 16d) . One side is straight with a pronounced corner notch. The opposite corner notch and midsection of the original edge are still intact, but the corner tang is broken. The point has an expanding stem. The burinlike flake removed across the base reduced the stem length and width. The distal end and adjacent edge were resharpened, although apparently not used.

One bison element recovered during TMM investigations with the general designation of stratum 4 exhibited human-induced modification. The proximal end of a bison left radius (892-202} was modified through dynamic loading, which opened the diaphysis and exposed the marrow (Fig. 17a) . Cone flaking on the interior fracture surface indicates the initial impact was on the posterior diaphysis just below the lateral tuberosity (Fig. 17b ) . The element was positioned on its anterior side. A rebound impact was not preserved, which may indicate a double anvil mode. The apex of the fracture is on the external lateral side. A number of overlapping flake scars occur along the anterior section of the fracture edge (Fig. 17c) . These scars and two adjacent internal ridges on the fracture surface are covered by polish. Flaking and polish are restricted to this area. While the element may have been used as a tool, possible carnivore tooth scoring below and parallel to the flaked edge makes the element suspect (Fig. 17d) . The radius was accessioned as "from M-4?". At Station M, the A horizon of the Lubbock Lake Soil was eroded. Based on bone preservation, the element is not from substratum 4A. If indeed the bone comes from stratum 4 at Station M, then it appears to have come from substratum 4B.

Three lithic artifacts also have the general designation of stratum 4. Artifacts 892-146 and 892-147 come from "near Station M," and artifact 892-148 was recorded as "across from and somewhat south of Station M." To date in this general vicinity of the reservoir cut, only substratum 4A and the A horizon of the Lubbock Lake Soil have yielded materials.

Artifact 892-146 ( Fig. 18a) is an expanding utilized flake (Aiibates agate) with a multifaceted platform and diffuse bulb. Utilization flaking occurs along the right dorsal lateral, the left dorsal lateral at mid-distal, and the right ventral lateral at midpoint. Artifact 892-147 (Edwards Formation chert) is a small, unmodified flake. Artifact 892-148 (silicified caliche) is a square, utilized flake with an unfaceted platform and a large, pronounced bulb (Fig. 18b) . Utilization flaking occurs on the dorsal side along the left lateral and distal end. A rounded, worn edge is noticeable, particularly at the distal left corner.

It is apparent from the above descriptions of cultural features and artifacts that Lubbock Lake was occupied at least periodically if not continuously throughout the Archaic. Moreover, most of the Archaic material was recovered using rather crude {by modern standards} excavation techniques. Based on Wheat's (1939 Wheat's ( , 1974 comments, numerous hearths were encountered in substratum 4B. A high concentration of artifacts and features can be seen in Wheat's (1974) Trench A West from units 90 to 180 and 200 to 240 (Fig. 5) . Unfortunately, the southwestern section of the trench which contained material from units 200 to 240 no longer exists due to destruction by construction activities. Deposits surrounding Trench A West from Datum B southwest to unit 180 basically are intact. The LLP oven (FA 16-1) is roughly 30 m northwest ofWPA unit 160 in Trench A West. The TMM excavators encountered several extensive bone beds, and Green (1962a) and Kelley (1974) uncovered hearths and camping debris. With these considerations in mind, the material that was recovered from the numerous occupations indicates the potential for a relatively rich Archaic data base at Lubbock Lake.

The most unusual feature or activity area encountered was the large oval basin (FA 16-1) interpreted as an oven. The lack of vertebrate material {burned or unburned) within and around the oven, the presence of very fine pure ash, a rock covering instead of rock lining, and the metate suggest the use of the baking oven as a vegetal processing area. Systematic plant exploitation intensified in the a em 0 i!!!!!!!!!liiiiiiiiiiiiil!!!!!!!5iiiiiiiiiiiil!!!!!!!!!i 5 Fig. 18 . Stratum 4 lithic tools: a, 892-146; b, 892-148. Archaic due in part to the reduction in the variety of animal protein resources. Features similar to this one are unknown elsewhere on the Llano Estacada.

Three projectile points (Trinity, Ellis, and Bulverde) were recovered from substratum 4B. This unit was deposited between about 5000 to about 4500 years B.P., providing an age range for the artifacts and demonstrating a contemporaneity.

Considerable archaeological material was recovered from the A horizon of the Lubbock Lake Soil. The age of this surface spans the Late Archaic into the Ceramic period. Therefore, not all of the material from this unit can be considered Late Archaic, as underscored by Wheat's (1974) recovery of sherds of Chupadero Black-on-White.

The Archaic is the longest cultural period on the Llano Estacada. However, relatively few sites are reported with Archaic occupations in well-stratified or well-dated contexts. The only documented Early Archaic feature on the Llano Estacada is at Lubbock Lake. Middle Archaic features are reported from Lubbock Lake, Blackwater Draw Locality #1 (Hester 1972) , and Little Sunday (Hughes 1955) . At Blackwater Draw Locality #1, Williams, Travis, Pedernales, and Pandale points were recovered from the "jointed sands" (Hester 1972:143-144) which is Unit F (Haynes 1975) , an eolian deposit dating to about 5000 to 4500 years B.P. (Holliday 1985d) . Associated activity areas and artifacts were not mentioned.
body_text.section: THE ARCHAIC ON THE LLANO EST ACADO

body_text.text: Several localities with Late Archaic associations are reported from the Llano Estacada in addition to Lubbock Lake. The "upper camping deposits" of the "lower midden zone" at Chalk Hollow (Wedel 1975) are about 2500 years old. These deposits contain corner-and side-notched projectile points similar to Late Archaic Marcos and Ensor which are more common in central Texas (Prewitt 1981; Weir 1976; Turner and Hester 1985) . The exact nature of Late Archaic occupations at Chalk Hollow was not reported.
body_text.section: THE ARCHAIC ON THE LLANO EST ACADO

body_text.text: At Little Sunday, Hughes (1955) reported Ellis and Palmillas points along with a number of other lithic tools, debitage, hearths, and burned rock. Several untyped, cornernotched, expanding stem, dart points, similar to Marcos, were recovered at Pete Creek (Parsons 1967:29-30) . Since these artifacts were mixed with protohistoric material, they give only an indication of Late Archaic occupation.
body_text.section: THE ARCHAIC ON THE LLANO EST ACADO

body_text.text: On the northern Llano Estacada, a number of campsites and bison kills were reported that are either Late Archaic or transitional Archaic to Ceramic. In the Mackenzie Reservoir area, camping features were tested at County Line, Blue Clay, and Deadman's Shelter (Hughes and Willey 1978) . Dart and arrow points and a variety of lithic tools, debris, ground stone, and hearths were found.
body_text.section: THE ARCHAIC ON THE LLANO EST ACADO

body_text.text: At Deadman's Shelter (Willey and Hughes 1978) , dart and arrow points were found in association with pottery. Radiocarbon dates Further evidence of this continuity is seen in numerous bison kills found east of the llano Estacada escarpment (Tunnell and Hughes 1955; Hughes 1977) . These kills (7 to 23 bison per kill) contained a variety of projectile points (Ellis, Marcos, Esnor, Pa!millas, Trinity, and Twilla). These sites were believed to be Late Archaic kills dating at around 2500 years ago based on radiocarbon dated kills with very similar projectile point assemblages from the lower Pecos region (Dibble 1968) . However, radiocarbon dates on bone from four kills averaged 1387 ± 112 years B.P. (A.D. 563 ± 112) (Hughes 1977: Table 2 ). If the bone dates can be accepted, they indicate that the sites are considerably younger, and, based on the association of dart points and ceramics at Deadman's Shelter (Willey and Hughes 1978) , the bone beds are from Ceramic times. Sites with mixed dart and arrow point assemblages also were found in Tule Canyon, just below Mackenzie Reservoir (Katz and Katz 1 976) . The number of archaeological sites in this area with both dart and ::3now points but lacking pottery suggests that the arrow point tradition preceded the Ceramic tradition.
body_text.section: THE ARCHAIC ON THE LLANO EST ACADO

body_text.text: Other sites on the Llano Estacado that were tested or excavated with indications of Archaic occupation include Floydada Country Club (Word 1963) , Montgomery (Word 1965) , Canyon City Country Club (Hughes n.d.) , Ray Thompson (Bandy 1977) , lake Theo (Harrison and Killen 1978) , and several sites in Sanford Reservoir on the Canadian River (Green 1967) . Lake Creek (Hughes 1962) may have a Late Archaic component, and burials near Amarillo (Jockerst 1971) and on the Taylor Ranch (Willey and Ubelaker 1976) , just east of the escarpment, may be Archaic.
body_text.section: THE ARCHAIC ON THE LLANO EST ACADO

body_text.text: Archaic materials were located in a number of surveys. Downstream from Lubbock Lake, Middle and Late Archaic materials were found on the surface of Yellowhouse Draw (Bandy et al. 1981; Johnson and Stafford 1976) . Archaic material was recovered from Caprock Canyon State Park (Willey and Hughes 1975) and from several sites in lower Tule Canyon (Katz and Katz 1976) . Warnica (1965) briefly described four Archaic sites on the Llano Estacada of eastern New Mexico. Seventeen Archaic sites were located in the Lake Meredith Recreation Area (Sanford Reservoir) and Alibates National Monument (Bandy 1977; Bousman 1974a Bousman , 1974b . Archaic artifacts also were recovered from the surface of "ly-4" (Riggs 1965) and Madsen lake (Bandy 1977) . Finally, Hughes (1974: 234) referred to ''scores of rich Archaic sites near springs along the eastern Caprock Escarpment.''
body_text.section: THE ARCHAIC ON THE LLANO EST ACADO

body_text.text: The well-dated and considerable vertebrate, sedimentologic, and pedologic record from lubbock Lake, with some limited data from other sites, can serve as a model for the environment during the Archaic on the Llano Estacada.

The vertebrate faunal record for substratum 2e and strata 3 and 4 at Lubbock lake basically is a modem one adapted to a mixedgrass to short-grass prairie with some brush (Table 3) . However, the mexican pocket gopher is a key faunal element Absent in strata 1 and 2, this gopher occurs only in strata 3 and 4 and again is absent in the A horizon of the lubbock Lake Soil (a stable land surface marking a return to moist conditions) and stratum 5. This gopher is the most arid adapted of all pocket gophers and only recently is extending its range back onto the Llano Estacada. Its presence denotes arid conditions.

Of the bison mandibles recovered in strata 3 and 4, most have teeth that exhibit unusually heavy and irregular wear. Growth patterns of the teeth and bones appear normal. A decrease in bison herd size or population does not seem apparent when compared to bison remains recovered in other strata. The amount of forage is difficult to judge, but the dental abnormalities denote poor range conditions due to excess grit on the vegetation. This grit may have been due to large amounts of dust in the air during this time.

Dillehay (197 4) proposed a model of bison presence and absence for the Southern Plains (Llano Estacada and Rolling P~ains) during the late Quaternary. The longest period of proposed bison absence is Absence Period I, which dates from 8000-7000 to 4500 years B.P. Dillehay (1974:182) commented that the only exceptions in this period are Blackwater Draw locality #1 and San Jon (Fig. 2) , but "these two sites are not repre-sentative of the Southern Plains, as they are on the western periphery of the region." Clearly, the data from lubbock lake now indicate that bison were present on the llano Estacada throughout the proposed Absence Period I. Lynott (1979) also has criticized the model, demonstrating that a number of problems exist with applying it in both time and space.

Substratum 2e records the beginning of eolian sedimentation at Lubbock lake, and strata 3 and 4 document massive eolian sedimentation, which suggests a reduction in vegetative cover probably due to a decrease in effective moisture. The highly calcareous nature of substratum 3/, in contrast to the highly siliceous stratum 2 immediately below, also suggests a warming trend (Holliday 1985b) .

These interpretations are supported by the limited data from the microvertebrate fauna, the invertebrate fauna (Pierce 1975) , and paleobotany (Thompson 1977) . This mid-Holocene drought is considered to be the local manifestation of the Altithermal (Antevs 194~, 1955) . Green (1962a, i 962b) proposed that stratum 4 represented the Altithermal. The additional LLP stratigraphic, sedimentologic, pedologic, and radiocarbon evidence indicates, however, that two episodes of aridity existed in the Altithermal, represented by substrata 3e (6400-5500 years B.P.) and 48 (5000-4500 years B.P.}. The episodes were separated by a brief (ca. 500 years) period of landscape stability represented by the Yellowhouse Soil which formed in stratum 3. Furthermore, the localized fluvial deposits (substratum 4A) inset against stratum 3 and the Yellowhouse Soil and buried by the eolian sediments of substratum 48 suggest a brief period of reactivation of springs, perhaps due to a rise in the water table resulting from an increase in precipitation.

Geologic data for the middle Holocene also are becoming available for other parts of Yellowhouse Draw and from Blackwater Draw, Running Water Draw, playa-lake basins, and dunes (Holliday 1982b (Holliday , 1983 (Holliday , 1985d Gile 1979 Gile , 1983 . These data clearly demonstrate that considerable eolian sedimentation occurred throughout the Llano Estacada at this time, apparently the result of a decrease in effective precipitation. These data also suggest that the two periods of middle Holocene drought identified at lubbock Lake were regional phenomena. Benedict and Olson (1978) and Benedict (1979) proposed a "Two-drought Aitithermal" for the western United States with aridity maxima at 7500 to 6500 and 6000 to 5500 years B.P. These ages are remarkably similar to those from lubbock Lake and the Llano Estacada considering that they are based on entirely different lines of evidence. The Altithermal maxima may have been reached at different times in different areas depending on the regional response to changes in atmospheric circulation. The evidence suggests that periodically at least (perhaps seasonally?), the environment of the Llano Estacado during the Middle Archaic was rather inhospitable. There were times when considerable amounts of dust were blowing across the Plains. In addition, temperatures may have been quite high, helping to reduce the amount of effective moisture received.

Beginning about 4500 years B.P. and continuing throughout the rest of the Archaic, the climate of the region ameliorated. Sedimentation ceased, and little erosion occurred, which resulted in the formation of the Lubbock Lake Soil at Lubbock lake and similar soils at other localities (HoUiday 1985d . This landscape stability indicates a change to more moist conditions, perhaps similar to today.

Although conditions may have been harsh during the Altithermal, the geologic record at Lubbock lake also documents the presence of some surface water throughout this time and the entire Archaic (Firstview Soil formation and substrata 3/, 4A, and 4~. The high carbonate content of substratum 3/ indicates that it was quite brackish. The nature of the water that produced substratum 4/ is not known, but the lower carbonate content suggests that it was intermediate in quality between the brackish waters of stratum 3 and the fresh water of stratum 2. The presence of surface water at Lubbock Lake during the Altithermal is in considerable contrast to the situation at Blackwater Draw Locality #1, where Archaic peoples apparently had to dig wells in order to reach the water table (Evans 1951; Green 1962b ).

Comparing the Archaic record of the Llano Estacada with the Archaic of adjoining areas is difficult for several reasons. Primarily, given the size of the Llano Estacada, relatively little data are available and what are available generally lack the type of features and diagnostic artifacts that allow regional comparisons. Good age control also is lacking from most of the sites on the Llano Estacada. Furthermore, very little is published, in a generally available form, on data for the Archaic from regions contiguous with the Llano Estacada. Almost nothing is known of this period from the upper Pecos Valley or the High Plains of the northern Texas panhandle north of the Canadian River. Very little data are available from the western Rolling Plains except for the few sites noted along the edge of the eastern escarpment of the Llano Estacada.

The Edwards Plateau of central and southwest Texas is the one adjacent area for which a considerable amount of published data exist (e.g., Prewitt 1981; Turner and Hester 1985) . The few diagnostic projectile points recovered in situ from sites on the Llano Estacada provide one of the few means for comparison. Blackwater Draw Locality #1 yielded Williams, Travis, Pandale, and Pedernales points dating to about 5000 to 4500 years B.P., and Bulverde, Trinity, and Ellis points were recovered at Lubbock Lake in deposits of the same age. In central and southwest Texas, these artifact types are not found commonly in association with each other. Travis and Pedernales points are a little later (4500-3000 years B.P.) and tend to be found in central Texas and the lower Pecos River region; Williams points (4500-2000 years B.P.) are more concentrated in central Texas; Pandale points generally are older (6000-4500 years B.P.) and found in the lower Pecos River region; Bulverde points (4000-3400 years B.P.) are widespread in central Texas; Ellis points are younger (2000 years B.P.) and widespread in north-central Texas; and Trinity points (4500-3000 years B.P.) are more common in north Texas (Suhm and Jelks 1962; Guderjan 1981; Guderjan and Morehead 1981; McKinney 1981; Prewitt 1981; Lynott 1978; Weir 1976; Turner and Hester 1985) . These very limited data suggest that certain projectile point types may vary considerably in age within Texas, depending on location, and that for as yet unknown reasons, designs spanning a long period of time in central and southwest Texas (6000 to less than 2000 years B.P.) were present on the Llano Estacada during the period 5000 to 4500 years B.P., the time of the second major drought.

D. Hughes (1984) recently reviewed the Archaic of western Oklahoma. Little data come from excavated sites, but some of the projectile points found in the few excavations and from the surface are similar to those from the Llano Estacada and Edwards Plateau (Bulverde, Ensor, Marcos, Trinity, Ellis). A single radiocarbon date was used to provide a maximum age of about 3000 years B.P. for the Ensor, Marcos, and Bulverde types. This scanty information makes comparisons difficult, although it appears that, as with the Edwards Plateau, some variation may occur in ages of certain so-called diagnostic artifacts.

The oven recovered at Lubbock Lake has some vague similarities with central Texas burned rock middens. These mounds of burned rocks also are Middle Archaic in age but are considerably larger (several to hundreds of meters in length), deeper (several meters), contained burned rock throughout (rather than ash deposits), and are most commonly built over a prepared basin (Kelley and Campbell 1942; Sorrow 1969; Prewitt 1981) . The oven also bears some similarities to features reported from the Gore Pit site in southwestern Oklahoma (Hammatt 1976) . These ash-filled, caliche-capped basins are larger (several meters across) and date to about 6000 years B.P.

Definitions and subdivisions of the Archaic are many and varied (Table 5) in part reflecting different approaches by the investigators and varying data bases, but also the regionalized character of this period. Previous substantive studies of the Archaic on the Llano Estacada are lacking, and therefore definitions and subdivisions were based on an arbitrary, general approach (e.g., Suhm and Jelks 1962) . Although modifying existing schemes from areas related by geographic Cassells 1984 Late Middle Early proximity or physiography is possible, this approach would not be productive for the Llano Estacado. The nearest areas with well-documented Archaic records are central Texas {e.g., Prewitt 1981) and eastern Oklahoma (Wyckoff 1984) . The paleoenvironments of these areas were so different from that of the Llano Estacado that attempts at fitting chronologies would yield misleading results. Other related areas such as the Southwest {e.g., Cordell 1984) , Central High Plains {e.g., Benedict and Olson 1978; Cassells 1983) , and western Oklahoma {D. Hughes 1984) have produced only very limited data.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: Although phases for the Archaic period cannot yet be assigned, such as in central (Weir 1976; Prewitt 1981) and Trans-Pecos {Prewitt 1983) Texas, a better definition and model than previously known is possible based on the Lubbock Lake data. While the Llano Estacado never was abandoned during this time, cultural changes and subsistence shifts appear to coincide with climatic changes and stresses. The model {Table 5) is based on climatic events, subsistence activities, and numerous radiocarbon ages. The Archaic on the Llano Estacado {8500-2000 years B.P.) now is characterized by a fluctuating mixed economy of systematic use of wild plant and animal resources, typified by a variety of dart point designs, within a time period marked by climatic change from the end of pluvial conditions through extreme xeric conditions to ameliorated mesic conditions, and denoted by the modernization of faunal and vegetational communities. The Archaic is subdivided into Early {8500-6400 years B.P.), Middle {6400-4500 years B.P.), and Late {4500-2000 years B.P.), following for the most part the three general climatic stages noted. The Early Archaic occurs during a time of environmental transition from the earliest Holocene warming trend into the Middle Holocene intense xeric conditions. Extinct bison exists into at least the early part of the Early Archaic and was experiencing stress expressed as size diminution. The Middle Archaic occurs during the Middle Holocene drought or Altithermal, a time of very dry and very warm conditions. Modern bison emerges by the beginning of this period, if not somewhat earlier. The Late Archaic occurs during a return to moister and somewhat cooler conditions, perhaps similar to those of today.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: The termination of the Late Archaic is marked by the introduction of ceramics and the bow and arrow into the region. However, climatically, the ameliorated conditions continued for another 1000 years. This 1 000-year period appears to be one of transition on the Llano Estacada from traditional Archaic lifeways denoted by the retention of Archaic point designs and bison kills but adoption of technological changes to the lifeways of various Ceramic-age groups in the region. This transitional period ends about the time of another climatic change towards a warming trend. Hughes (1974) labeled this transitional period on the Llano Estacada as the Southern Plains Woodland period, characterized by influence from eastern groups. This same transitional phenomenon is seen in central Texas and is labeled the Neoarchaic (Prewitt 1981 ) . It also lasted about 1000 years but occurred 1 000 years later.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: Pluvial conditions ended by the beginning of the Early Archaic, which is warmer and dustier than in the preceding Paleo-Indian period but still milder than in the succeeding period. Bison hunting continued within an overall reduction of animal food resources. Traditional dietary supplements such as muskrat and puddle ducks no longer are available (Johnson 1983a) . Johnson (1983b) proposed, based on evidence presented by Bamforth (1985) , that systematic plant food use may have had its origins during the end of the Paleo-Indian period in response to nutritional stress, heralding the beginnings of the Archaic.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: The Middle Archaic is characterized by two lengthy droughts, the earlier one lasting about 900 years (6400-5500 years B.P.) and the later about 500 years (5000-4500 years B.P.), with a 500-year period of respite (5500-5000 years B.P.) in between the two. That period of respite brought relatively cooler, moister conditions and a cessation to blowing dust Although not yet demonstrated, it is suspected that two peaks of intensive plant use occurred, coinciding with the two droughts and a resurgence of the relative importance of bison to the subsistence base during the period of respite. The Late Archaic is marked by an ameliorated climate of cooler, moister conditions and return of a stable landscape similar to modern conditions. Range conditions improved, and another resurgence of the relative importance of bison is postulated.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: To reiterate, the general Archaic economy is a mixed economy of systematic plant and animal use. At no time does it appear that one or the other resource formed an exclusive subsistence base. A model is presented of hypothesized relative importance of plant and animal food resources to the mixed economy throughout the Archaic. Actual percentages are unknown, and the contrast is one of more or less importance based on limited data. With the late Paleo-Indian as the base line, five major shifts within the Archaic mixed economy are postulated, appearing to coincide with the climatic shifts occurring during that time.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: Shift 1 (8500-6400 years B.P.): Bison is relatively more important than plants to the mixed economy during the Early Archaic, although less important than during the late Paleo-Indian. The suspected age of the FA4-1 bison kill/butchering locale, based on stratigraphic position and bracketing radiocarbon ages (Holliday et al. 1983 (Holliday et al. , 1985 , is about 8000 years B.P. The distribution pattern and condition of the elements suggest selectivity for the large muscle masses. This pattern is in contrast to one of near total utilization of muscle resources seen in the earlier Paleo-Indian (Johnson 1983a (Johnson , 1983b Johnson and Holliday 1980) but follows the later Paleo-Indian pattern (Johnson and Holliday 1981) of selectivity.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: Shift 2 (6400-5500 years B.P.): Plant products become relatively more important than bison during the first drought of the Middle Archaic. Although specific evidence is not yet known from Lubbock Lake, an analogy is drawn with that of the second drought. In the adjacent Rolling Plains of western Oklahoma, the Gore PH site (Hammatt 1976) with its vegetal processing pits dates to this time (ca. 6000 years B.P.).
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: Shift 3 (5500-5000 years B.P.): Bison emerges once again as the relatively more important food source in the mixed economy during the Middle Archaic period of respite. Several bison bone beds are known at Lubbock Lake which date between 5300 to 4900 years B.P. (Holliday et al. 1983 (Holliday et al. , 1985 .
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: Shift 4 (5000-4500 years B.P.): The second drought signals another peak in intensive plant use. The oven (FA 16-1) is in use during this period and dates to about 4800 years B.P.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: Shift 5 (4500-1000 years B.P.): Bison once again becomes the relatively more important food source as the climate ameliorates and vegetation improves. This role continues into the Ceramic period until about 1 000 years B.P., when other resource utilization patterns emerge.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: The projectile points found on the Llano Estacado which are similar to central and north-central Texas variants suggest ties with these areas. However, given the consistent dating of these types to the second drought period on the Llano Estacado and the consistently later dating in the other areas, the influence may be spreading from the Llano Estacado to these other areas instead of the traditional view of the other way. In essence, the origin of these point designs may be the Llano Estacado. Their flourescence in central Texas in particular may be a phenomenon related to the continuation of intensive plant processing (burned rock middens) which began around 5000 years B.P. and extended to about 2250 years B.P. (Prewitt 1981}, but intensive plant use appears to diminish on the Llano Estacado by ca. 4500 years B.P.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: The climate of central Texas appears to have been more favorable than that during the Altithermal on the Llano Estacado. Paleobotanical and paleohydrological data from along the eastern and southeastern Edwards Plateau Bryant and Shafer 1977; Baker and Penteado-Orellana 1977) and from the lower Pecos River of the southwestern Edwards Plateau (Story and Bryant 1966; Bryant and Shafer 1977; Patton and Dibble 1982) indicate that these regions were not significantly drier than they are today. Central Texas may have acted as a refuge area for certain populations from the Llano Estacado. A similar hypothesis was proposed by Benedict (1979) and Benedict and Olson (1978}, with the Front Range of the Colorado Rockies acting as a refugium for Archaic peoples during the Altithermal on the Northern High Plains.
body_text.section: AN ARCHAIC MODEL FOR THE LLANO ESTACADO

body_text.text: Some general observations can be made 48 about the Archaic on the Llano Estacado. Known sites from the earlier part of the Archaic (ca. 8500-4500 years B.P.) are scarce. The latter part of this period corresponds to the Altithermal (Antevs 1948 (Antevs , 1955 . Although the exact nature of the Altithermal still is subject to some debate, evidence from the Llano Estacado indicates that it was drier and warmer, as originally postulated, and probably occurred as two droughts.

Dibble (1968) and Hughes (1977) noted similarities in projectile point designs and the use of the jump technique in bison kills along the northern edge of the Llano Estacado and in the lower Pecos River area. However, the radiocarbon ages from the Llano Estacado are considerably younger than those from the lower Pecos River. The dates from the northern Llano Estacado kills were determined on bone, whereas the others are on charcoal. The similarities between these sites are so striking that the bone dates may be subject to question. If reliable, however, they indicate the continuation of some aspects of an Archaic lifeway while adopting technological changes and a transition into Ceramic lifeways.

Adjacent regions for which some substantive data occur on the Archaic are northcentral Texas-western Oklahoma and central Texas. Pandale, Travis, Bulverde, Pedernales, Williams, Trinity, and Ellis points, found at Lubbock Lake and Blackwater Draw Locality #1 , date to between 5000 and 4500 years B.P. (the second drought). Pandale points are common in the Trans-Pecos, dating from ca. 6000 years B.P. (Prewitt 1983) . Travis, Bulverde, Pedernales, and Williams are common in central Texas, while Trinity and Ellis are common in north-central Texas. However, these latter six types date later in time in these regions than on the Llano Estacado.

Archaeological remains from the later part of the Archaic (ca. 4500-2000 years B.P.) are more common on the Llano Estacado. This period corresponds to Antevs's (1948, 1955) Medithermal, which is considered to represent a return to a cooler, moister climate. This interpretation is supported by evidence for landscape stability (soil formation rather than eolian deposition) throughout the Llano Estacado. Hughes (1974) postulated that eastern populations, ancestral to Plains Caddo, moved onto the Plains during the Medi-thermal.

Although a reduced population of the Plains is suggested during the Altithermal, and conditions apparently were quite inhospitable, evidence for abandonment of the Llano Estacado is lacking. Occupations at Lubbock Lake occurred throughout this time, probably because water was available which also would support vegetation and attract game. However, some groups of people may have sought refuge in central Texas.

That the Plains were not abandoned during the Altithermal is a view in general agreement with Willey and Phillips (1958) and Stephenson (1965) . However, Hughes (1974) , like Jennings (1957) and Stephenson (1965) , believed that Early Archaic Plains hunting cultures, which developed from Paleq-lndian groups, moved eastward during the Altithermal and were replaced by Desert cultures moving out of the Southwest onto the Plains.

Given the data available, the model presented is one of cultural continuity and in situ development in response to changing climatic conditions. Projectile points found on the Llano Estacado similar to central and northcentral Texas variants, although suggesting ties with these areas, date earlier in time and indicate the possibility that the cultural influence was going from the Llano Estacado to these other areas and, therefore, do not reflect movement onto the Llano Estacado by eastern peoples.

The pale olive hues are a result of reduction (gleying) of 4A after deposition which induced the chemical weathering and color change of the bone. At Station E, eroded 4A, 4 to 75 em thick, is preserved overlying 3/.

FIGREF10.text: work in Area 5 yielded the distal end of a left femur (TTU-A22446) of a pronghorn antelope, a partial left P 4 (TTU-A22447) of a bison, and a utilized flake (TTU-A24608). The rectangular flake (silicified caliche) exhibits bifacial utilization flaking along the distal end and dorsal unifacial utilization flaking along both distolaterals.

FIGREF11.text: [3], right, 78.0 mm; 892-3E[19], right, 76.6 mm) and two females(892-3E [18], right, 70.1 mm; 892-3E, left, 68.1 mm). These four mandibles had their teeth fully erupted and in wear and therefore represent adults of 5.5 years or greater. Mandible 892-4E [3] exhibits heavy and abnormal wear of P 4 -M 2 with cupping of the third cusp of M 3 . Mandible 892-3E[18]    exhibits heavy and abnormal wear of P 3 and M 1 , and cupping of the third cusp of M 3 . Mandible 892-3E [19] exhibits cupping of the third cusp of M 3 .The other three mandibles indicate the presence of the additional two bison, both subadults. Mandible 892-3E (right) exhibits slight wear on the P 2 and M 3 , indicating an approximate age of 3 years. Mandible 892-3E [16] exhibits an erupted M 2 in very slight wear and an unerupted M 3 , indicating an approximate age of 1.5 years. Mandible 892-3E (left) exhibits an erupted M 1 in beginning wear and unerupted M 2 -M 3 , indicating an approximate age of 0.5 years.
